title: 114_hr4447
content: The "Opioid and Heroin Epidemic Emergency Supplemental Appropriations Act" appropriates funds for law enforcement programs, specifically for state and local law enforcement assistance under the Department of Justice's Office of Justice Programs. The "Opioid and Heroin Epidemic Emergency Supplemental Appropriations Act" allocates $200,000,000 for state and local law enforcement assistance through the Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant program for drug treatment, enforcement, prevention, and education programs. The "Community Oriented Policing Services Programs" receive an additional $10,000,000 for competitive grants to State law enforcement agencies in States with high rates of primary treatment admissions for heroin or other opioids. This amount is designated as an emergency requirement. $240,000,000 is designated as an emergency requirement for Substance Abuse Treatment, with allocations for prevention, medication-assisted treatment, and recovery services. The curr_chunk summarizes the program within the Center for Substance Abuse Treatment. $20,000,000 allocated for Substance Abuse Prevention under the Strategic Prevention Framework/Partnership for Success program within the Center for Substance Abuse Prevention, designated as an emergency requirement by Congress. $5,000,000 allocated for mental health in the Project AWARE program within the Center for Mental Health Services, designated as an emergency requirement by Congress. The Congress allocated $50,000,000 for "Injury Prevention and Control" to enhance State-level prescription drug abuse prevention efforts, including improving monitoring programs and collaboration among States. This amount is designated as an emergency requirement. Additionally, funding was allocated to the National Institute on Drug Abuse within the National Institutes of Health. The Congress allocated $30,000,000 to the National Institute on Drug Abuse for drug abuse prevention under the Public Health Service Act. The funding is designated as an emergency requirement. The Congress allocated $40,000,000 to the "Public Health and Social Services Emergency Fund" for coordinating and responding to the national heroin and opioid drug abuse crisis. The funding is designated as an emergency requirement.
